70TH YEAR

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, MARYLAND, APRIL 29, 1966

Shriver Sets
Jazz, Ballet
Two cultural events, running the gamut of musical
Oxperience from jazz to ballet, will take place this
Weekend in the person of Dave Brubeck and the Balt/it/lore City Ballet Company.
The Dave Brubeck Quartet will play their gig tonight at 8:30 in Shriver under the sponsorship of the
1/ICA and the Junior Class. Brubeck, to many the
Mainstay of progressive jazz, has garnered international acclaim in recognition for his contribution to
laze.
The Baltimore City Ballet will present their program
at classical and modern dance Sunday night at 8:30'
P.M. also at Shrivel.. The five-year old company congists of 25 dancers and is Baltimore's only dance organization.
The Ballet group appearing Sunday will include
visiting artists from the Metropolitan Opera and Manhattan Festival Ballet Companies. The production will
be under the direction of Danny Diamond.
Jazz buffs tonight will be treated to improvisation
end polyrhythms. Brubeck believes that improvisation
Is the heart of jazz. Brubeck thinks that jazz can be
Written, and that ultimately the dividing line between
Classical music and jazz will disappear.
The Brubeck Quartet is well known for its successes
In the Time series of albums, "Time Out," "Time
Purther Out," and "Count Down Time in Outer
Space." It IS in these recordings in which the jazz
stsartet experiences polyrhythms.
Along with Brubeck will appear Paul Desmond on
idto sax, Joe Morello as percussionist, and Gene
Wright on bass. Brubeck pounds on the piano. Each
itl( the other members of the Brubeck Quartet are famous in their own right.
The program to be presented to ballet lovers Sunday
Will include several Brahms waltzes, described by Diamond as "romantic in style and feeling, and classicai
In technique."
Also presented will be Children's Corner by Claude
Debussey, seen as "classical ballet with some modern.
One is stylized and contrasted against a more modern
one," explains Diamond. The Jazz Suite done to the
music of Robert Prince and a period piece by Mozart
Will round out the program.
Diamond describes romanticism as a form in ballet
ma characterized by toe dancing and white filmy
drosses. "Poses and forms are important in this kind
Of dance." Naturalism is described by Diamond as
4'people doing as they really do. It is a rebirth of expression, but for a whole group rather than one
dancer."
Modern dance is seen by the director of the Baltimore City Ballet Company as a "reaction to the impulse of the music. The different eras of the dance is
simply a philosophical difference. Modem dance is a
result of meaning inside the dancer rather than Victorian representation of the romantic."
Tickets for the ballet are available at the YMCA
office and Fred Walker's Music Store for $1, $1.50,
and $2.

"B. Fenster"
Dated for May
Theatre Hopkins will close its season on May 12
With William Snyder's The Days and Nights of Beebee
Fenstermaker to be presented in the Barn.
The play, which ran off-Broadway for one year
during the 1962-63 season, received wide acclaim as
one of the best contemporary American plays. Richard
Gilman, writing in Commonweal. states that it is
"informed by an acute sense of what it means to be
alive at this moment in this place; that is to say now.
In America, where the meaning of existence is fuzzier
DOW than almost anywhere else."
The role of Beebee will be portrayed by Jane Singer.
a member of the new professional company at the
Washington Theatre Club. Miss Singer has appeared
this year in John Dos Passos' U.S.A.. Anouilh's Romeo
and Jeanette and in the musical Ernest in Love.
Also appearing will be Elsa Rowel, the wife of a
student at Hopkins and herself a graduate of the Yale
Drama School.
Irvin Turner will follow up his Theatre Hopkins
roles in The Killer and Do You Know the Milky Way,
as the Iruterviewer in the Snyder play.
The play will be directed by Ed Golden, Jr., with
sets by James Edmund Brady. The production will run
May 12-15 and May 19-22. Tickets cost $2 and are
available at the Public Relations Office in Shrivel',

American folk music idiom known as Jazz. This extravaganza, sponsored by the junior class, will be
followed later this evening with the Y.M.C.A. sponsoring Brubeck in concert; putting his fingers where

By JOE WEINBERG
Not that we don't appreciate the effort boys. We
know how you all are just dying to bring back the
"The Difference" committee closed its fund raising
drive today with the comiletion of the solicitation of
the undergraduate body. As of last Tuesday, a total of
$6,000 had been raised. Further donations will be accepted by the Financial Aid Office in Maryland Hall.

!

L

Difference
Hits $6,000

The reported figure includes an anonymous $1,000
donation received this week, a $1,000 contribution from
the Biophysics Department, and approximately $1,500
in proceeds from The Boys from Syracuse. The figure
does not include pledges. Final figures will be published
In next week's News-Letter.
The committee, under the co-chairmanship of Barbara Ellis, a graduate student in Chemistry, Thomas
Carpenter, and Dr. Philip Hartman of Biology, expects the final total to be higher than the original
goal of $8,000. Dr. Hartman sent a letter to his faculty
solicitors indicating that the committee hoped to be
able to raise $12,000, and thus send three underprivileged students to Hopkins rather than two.
Student Contributions Low
This opthnism is due to the fact that the bulk of
the contributions so far have come from relatively few
sources. Only five departments in the faculty have
contributed on an organized basis, Biology, Romance
Languages, Biophysics, Chemistry, and Philosophy.
The Humanities and Social Sciences have not as yet
responded to the solicitations. Students themselves
have contributed very little, with only $1,000 coming
from students, and most of these contributors have
been graduate students.
The lack of undergraduate participation is partly
attributed to the fact that the undergraduate solicitation was delayed until this week.
The letters that were to be distributed to the offcampus students could not be given out. The Post
Office has recently refused to allow the stuffing of the
mail boxes in Gilman Hall. All mail must have a name
and box number on it, and the committee did not have
the manpower necessary to perform this task.
Sandy Cohn, who recently took charge of undergraduate solicitation, is expected to take action in the
near future to increase the student participation on
the drive.
"Syracuse" Contributes
Last weekend's performance of The Boys from Syracuse aided the drive. In addition to donating the proceeds of the show to "The Difference" fund, the show
also entertained .ft hundred inner-city high school
students Friday night.

The Dave Brubeck Quartet rests after recording
their most recent hit record; Take Five.
glory days from High School, and that a great deal of
G.0.-like effort has been spent recreating just the
proper atmosphere and spirit here at what some people
thought was a University. I guess we were wrong.
Honest Injun, guys, can't you do any better? Just
how many yews is Dave Brubeok going to have to
play the same saccharine music at Hopkins weekends
before anyone gets tired of it? It would be too much
to ask for someone who has something significant to
say—like Ornettet Coleman, maybe? Or John Lewis?
Or Milt Jackson? Or Miles Davis? But no: this, I
imagine, would require a modicum of imagination,
vision even; and this, one can bet any ranch on, is
one thing of which we can be sure the talented organizers of this weekend have not even the -slightest
conception. No, we must have Brubeck. It's like an
unwritten law, a gospel from the mount. Brubeck, they
say, is cool. Ergo, here he comes to Hopkins. Home of
cool. (Suggestion Student Council: rent yourselves out
as air-conditioners for the summer.)
But that dance. Grrr! If that isn't the most
ludicrous collection of no-talent, no-name, no-nothing
performers I have ever heard of—come to think of it,
has anyone ever heard of these people? Or are they
another of these Baltimore wonder bands from Hollywood Park? As usual, the dance can be expected to
be the already worn out cliche Johnny horror show
with more drunks (and unseemly drunks to boot) to
the square inch than any place outside the Central
Jail.
I don't know; is this really fun? Someone must
think so. Does anyone think so?

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL 29, 1966

Two Concert Series Campus Parking
At J.H.U. Next Year Prob. Examined
By TIM OLIVER
Half the subscriptions to the
1966-67 Hopkins concert series
have been sold to students, faculty and alumni, and sales will
soon be opened to the public.
Concert lovers will be offered an
additional treat by the annual
Baltimore Chamber Music Society series.
The University series, of six
concerts supported by the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation, will run, except for one
concert, Sundays in Shriver Hall.
The Chamber Music Society
series, featuring, as in seasons
past, artists of international
fame in programs of both standard and contemporary works,
will be held Sundays at 3:30 in
the auditorium of the Baltimore
Museum of Art.
University Series
The Shriver series will open
on November 13 with the Julhard String Quartet, called by

Quartetto Italiano

The campus parking problem
remains a perplexing one which
has yet to be solved. There are
approximately eight thousand
campus authorized vehicles for
some one thousand parking
spaces.

This situation is alleviated
somewhat by the fact that 5800
of the parking permits are issued to night students, but the
permits issued to day students,
faculty, employees, and guests
tax the present parking facilities.

Campus Notes
Spring Glee
The annual Spring concert of
the Hopkins Glee Club and the
Hopkins Orchestra will feature
parts two and three of Handel's
"Messiah". The concert will also
feature the voices of the Mary
Washington College Choir and
the solo voices of Laurie Kopec,
soprano; Ralph Marquis, Tenor;
and Frank Whitmore, bass.

Tau Tutors

In an effort to provide interThe University created the ested students with majors in the
Campus Traffic and Parking
Committee several years ago to
study the situation.
Besides issuing permits, the
committee must maintain the
parking lots and enforce its regulations. The committee makes
regulations it feels are necessary
for the safety of the campus
community. The blocking of
roads creates a fire hazard, prevents the passage of emergency
vehicles and hinders delivery of
necessary supplies.
The committee does not have
the funds to investigate the
problem of increasing the parking facilities. The university
authorized the hiring of a professional planning service to investigate this problem. The report of this group is expected in
the near future.

Curriculum Committee
The current plight of undergraduate education at
Hopkins is a well-established fact. Poor graduate instruction, insufficient course offerings in most departments, the small size of the teaching faculty, and incompetent advising have been lamented before. In the
recently compiled Report of the Undergraduate Committee for Curriculum Studies, its authors have successfully laid bare the relationship between these problems
and the general Hopkins approach to education, also providing concrete suggestions for improving the situation.
Because the departments are extremely graduatebriented, and due to the demands of the "publish or
perish" doctrine, the attention of the faculty is diverted,
not unwillingly, from the undergraduate student body.
Furthermore, the Report states, "proposals that the administration act to alter this imbalance involves a transgression of the traditional departmental autonomy. Most
faculty members feel that such autonomy should remain
because it preserves the freedom of the scholar." Many
administrators, we might add, go along with this philosophy.
While this approach embodies the "uniqueness"
of Hopkins, some modification is presently called for.
The administration will he characteristicly slow to react, although the combination of the Schools of Philosophy and Engineering Science into one School of Arts
and Sciences suggests that interdepartmental communication could improve, facilitating changes in basic academic requirements and scheduling, and encouraging
the establishment of more interdepartmental courses.
More importantly, the administration could encourage
professors to teach more courses by awarding promotions to good teachers as well as by increasing their
aalaries.
For any real improvement to take place, however,
the faculty in the various departments will have to
modify their views in favor of increased teaching responsibilities. Only in this way can qualified and interested graduate students receive the opportunity to teach
specialized courses in their particular fields, as has been
suggested, thus helping to alleviate the shortage of
courses. More thorough supervision and coordination
of graduate instructors also requires the belief by professors that the effort is worth it. There is no reason why
the departments on their own cannot effect the necessary
changes, if they are but willing to employ the current
departmental system more flexibly.
Dealing with departments individually and directly
proved a successful approach to the Undergraduate
Committee on Curriculum Studies in writing its report.
Professors were both frank and at least open to ideas.
In continuing to follow this approach, the Committee
may find the departments more responsive to the suggestions proposed in its Report.
The Committee itself currently hold ad hoe status,
view of its accomplishments to date, there seems
in
and
to he no reason to change it. Its greatest asset is the fact

THEATRE

'Syracuse'Funny Despite Faults
The Boys from Syracuse was a
funny play. It was not great
theater, it was not meant to be
great theater, but it was funny.
It was an attempt on the part
of one group of people to cause
another group of people to forget themselves for a moment and
laugh out loud. It succeeded admirably. One can not ask more
of a musical comedy.
The play can be criticized at
many points. It was amateurish,
many of the lines were trite,
slapstick cliches. Some of the
songs were badly written, badly
sung. But the production made
no pretense of being professional, and the trite lines were those
of George Abbott, not Theatre
Hopkins. The tone of the production was light, and it may be
said that those involved in producing the play viewed the task
of production and presentation
with just the right degree of seriousness. Never does the play become 80 heavy handed, the actors
so engrossed in themselves that
the primary object of the play,
humor, is forgotten.
None of the music can be described as great, but "Falling in
Love With Love" and "This

and over the years have achieved

REPUBLICAN BIAS

The Nixon Legacy: Circa 1966
By GEOFFREY LEBAR
It is clear now that the 1966
elections will in some way be a
referendum on the Viet Nam
War. Withdrawal or escalation
will not be the main issue,
though. Since all the Republican
candidates will be patriotic
Americans, their strategy will
not be to undermine the war
effort. The issue will center
around what Ambass:sador Goldberg confusingly calls the "credi-

bility gap." In simple terms this
means one's confidence or lack
of confidence in the government's
determination to carry out a
policy which it talks about.
The limited war in South Viet
Nam has lost much of its limited
character. The supply of career
soldiers, high school drop-outs,
and voluntary enlistees has been
used up. The tentacles of the
draft have now extended to

many college seniors who were
on their rightful way to graduate school. We have many such
people at Hopkins. Thousands of
other students will be taking
army scholastic tests to maintain
their IIS status. As more men
are touched by the war, a higher
interest in our Viet Nam policy
will develop.
Republicans must be very
careful and avoid reckless statements on this most serious international problem. Republicans
should look back to the legacy
of the Eisenhower and Nixon
years for advise on the war issue.
In those 8 years, not only was
peace maintained, but where
limited troop action was needed
It was carried out with dispatch
and success (Lebanon). In situations where long term stalemate
wars or unbearable political
tensions would result, Eisenhower and Nixon restrained
themselves (Hungary). John
Foster Dulles preached "brinkmanship" everywhere, but used

nuclear weapons and bombs nowhere.
Geography and logistics are
working against the U.S. in Viet
Nam as well as internal political
trouble. But these difficulties
should have been assessed before
the first U.S. adviser was killed
there in December, 1961. Obviously many mistakes were
made, especially concerning the
Diem government. As the Republicans fielded a candidate in
1952 who was able to end conflict in Korea in an honorable
fashion, so they may again in
1968.
Ironically in the Presidential
campaign of 1960, Richard Nixon
chose to stand and fight on the
foreign policy issue. Unfortunately, Quemoy and Matsu. Cuba,
Hungary, and Lebanon did not
stimulate the people. The nonexistent missile gap held the
stage as the defense issue.
The Nixon legacy on foreign
affairs is strikingly related by
Theodore White in his book,

1960. In the meeting by which a
Vice-Presidential candidate was
chosen, there was a disagreement
as to whether the candidate
should be knowledgeable in
domestic or foreign policy. Governor Stratton of Illinois said:
"You can say all you want to
about foreign affairs, but what's
really important is the price of
hogs in Chicago and St. Louis.'
Nixon declared, "If you ever let
them the Democrats) campaign
only on domestic issues, they'll
beat us—our only hope is to
keep it on foreign policy."
Theodore White relates a
memorable speech of Nixon's at
Peachtree Street and Hurt Park
in Atlanta, Georgia on August
26, 1960. Nixon said, ". . May
I turn now to what I believe is
the overriding issue confronting
u.s in this election campaign..
You know what it is. Look at
those boys sitting around that
pool. We want those boys to
grow up in a world of Peace
without Surrender. (Applause)
Because we can have the best
social security program and the
best health program and the
best job that anybody can possibly imagine and it Isn't going
to make any difference if we're
not around to enjoy it. . . I sapto you today that there is no
man in the world who has had
more experience and who has
shown more ability to deal with
the Communist leaders across
the conference table than the
man I trust will be the next
Vice-President, Henry Cabot
Lodge, our representative at the
U.N. .. ." (White, p. 323-4) Republican leaders should dust off
those 1960 Nixon speeches about
Peace without Surrender and
then ask for the people's vote in
1966 and 1968.

To the Editors:
The Kline article (April 1,
1965) shot through with half
truths, generalizations, and typical Radio Moscow phrasing, suggests little more that the frustrating mewlings of a small boy
whose father has forced him to
stop using crayons on the walls.
Either as a statement of SDS
policy or as a factual account of
the Waverly incident it fails
miserably.
Mr. Kline, the breadth of your
knowledge is truly astounding.
You seem to be an expert on the
inner workings of the modern
American corporation; you have,
no doubt, worked in top management positions for a number
of years. You profess to have
first hand information on our
foreign policy; undoubtedly Dean
Rusk calls you in regularly for
private briefings. And your firsthand account of what really goes
on in Vietnam is truly remarkable, particularly for one who
objects violently (oops, sorry,
non-violently) to being sent

there; how many months have
you spent in Vietnam as an onthe-spot observer? Lawyer, economist, foreign affairs expert,
political scientist, management
consultant, war correspondent:
how wonderful to have all this
in one so young!
Ah, but there is a fly in the
ointment; the true hoppie liberalarts-well-rounded-etc.
outlook
seems to be missing! Have you
visited the ghetto that is East
Berlin, Mr. Klein? Have you
talked with the refugees from
the Hungarian massacre of 1956?
Have you been corresponding
regularly with any of our men
in Vietnam? Or is this to be considered just a typical Wall Streetcapitalist-inperialist - aggressor propaganda, something that just
isn't done by Loyal SDS members? How is it that we never
see SDS protest any wars but
those in which SDS member!.
may have to fight?
Let's be serious, Mr. Klein. TI-w
guys over there are fighting
not to preserve our "economic
spheres of interest" (I presume
you mean by that that our corporations have huge holdings in
rice paddies?) — but to keep
the boat from rockIng while you
get on your soap box and
squawk about what they're doing. They're fighting to preserve
the rich American system which
now feeds, clothes, teaches,
houses, and pleasures you-the
same system you are castigating.
Bluntly, you're living as a leech
on their labors—which is pretty
disguisting in itself — but to
have you protest their labors
would be ridiculous were it not
so revolting.
Richard Oles

coach of the Fencing team.

70TH YEAR

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, MARYLAND, APRIL 29, 1966

Shriver Sets
Jazz, Ballet
Two cultural events, running the gamut of musical
Oxperience from jazz to ballet, will take place this
Weekend in the person of Dave Brubeck and the Balt/it/lore City Ballet Company.
The Dave Brubeck Quartet will play their gig tonight at 8:30 in Shriver under the sponsorship of the
1/ICA and the Junior Class. Brubeck, to many the
Mainstay of progressive jazz, has garnered international acclaim in recognition for his contribution to
laze.
The Baltimore City Ballet will present their program
at classical and modern dance Sunday night at 8:30'
P.M. also at Shrivel.. The five-year old company congists of 25 dancers and is Baltimore's only dance organization.
The Ballet group appearing Sunday will include
visiting artists from the Metropolitan Opera and Manhattan Festival Ballet Companies. The production will
be under the direction of Danny Diamond.
Jazz buffs tonight will be treated to improvisation
end polyrhythms. Brubeck believes that improvisation
Is the heart of jazz. Brubeck thinks that jazz can be
Written, and that ultimately the dividing line between
Classical music and jazz will disappear.
The Brubeck Quartet is well known for its successes
In the Time series of albums, "Time Out," "Time
Purther Out," and "Count Down Time in Outer
Space." It IS in these recordings in which the jazz
stsartet experiences polyrhythms.
Along with Brubeck will appear Paul Desmond on
idto sax, Joe Morello as percussionist, and Gene
Wright on bass. Brubeck pounds on the piano. Each
itl( the other members of the Brubeck Quartet are famous in their own right.
The program to be presented to ballet lovers Sunday
Will include several Brahms waltzes, described by Diamond as "romantic in style and feeling, and classicai
In technique."
Also presented will be Children's Corner by Claude
Debussey, seen as "classical ballet with some modern.
One is stylized and contrasted against a more modern
one," explains Diamond. The Jazz Suite done to the
music of Robert Prince and a period piece by Mozart
Will round out the program.
Diamond describes romanticism as a form in ballet
ma characterized by toe dancing and white filmy
drosses. "Poses and forms are important in this kind
Of dance." Naturalism is described by Diamond as
4'people doing as they really do. It is a rebirth of expression, but for a whole group rather than one
dancer."
Modern dance is seen by the director of the Baltimore City Ballet Company as a "reaction to the impulse of the music. The different eras of the dance is
simply a philosophical difference. Modem dance is a
result of meaning inside the dancer rather than Victorian representation of the romantic."
Tickets for the ballet are available at the YMCA
office and Fred Walker's Music Store for $1, $1.50,
and $2.

"B. Fenster"
Dated for May
Theatre Hopkins will close its season on May 12
With William Snyder's The Days and Nights of Beebee
Fenstermaker to be presented in the Barn.
The play, which ran off-Broadway for one year
during the 1962-63 season, received wide acclaim as
one of the best contemporary American plays. Richard
Gilman, writing in Commonweal. states that it is
"informed by an acute sense of what it means to be
alive at this moment in this place; that is to say now.
In America, where the meaning of existence is fuzzier
DOW than almost anywhere else."
The role of Beebee will be portrayed by Jane Singer.
a member of the new professional company at the
Washington Theatre Club. Miss Singer has appeared
this year in John Dos Passos' U.S.A.. Anouilh's Romeo
and Jeanette and in the musical Ernest in Love.
Also appearing will be Elsa Rowel, the wife of a
student at Hopkins and herself a graduate of the Yale
Drama School.
Irvin Turner will follow up his Theatre Hopkins
roles in The Killer and Do You Know the Milky Way,
as the Iruterviewer in the Snyder play.
The play will be directed by Ed Golden, Jr., with
sets by James Edmund Brady. The production will run
May 12-15 and May 19-22. Tickets cost $2 and are
available at the Public Relations Office in Shrivel',

By JOE WEINBERG
Not that we don't appreciate the effort boys. We
know how you all are just dying to bring back the
"The Difference" committee closed its fund raising
drive today with the comiletion of the solicitation of
the undergraduate body. As of last Tuesday, a total of
$6,000 had been raised. Further donations will be accepted by the Financial Aid Office in Maryland Hall.

!

L

Difference
Hits $6,000

The reported figure includes an anonymous $1,000
donation received this week, a $1,000 contribution from
the Biophysics Department, and approximately $1,500
in proceeds from The Boys from Syracuse. The figure
does not include pledges. Final figures will be published
In next week's News-Letter.
The committee, under the co-chairmanship of Barbara Ellis, a graduate student in Chemistry, Thomas
Carpenter, and Dr. Philip Hartman of Biology, expects the final total to be higher than the original
goal of $8,000. Dr. Hartman sent a letter to his faculty
solicitors indicating that the committee hoped to be
able to raise $12,000, and thus send three underprivileged students to Hopkins rather than two.
Student Contributions Low
This opthnism is due to the fact that the bulk of
the contributions so far have come from relatively few
sources. Only five departments in the faculty have
contributed on an organized basis, Biology, Romance
Languages, Biophysics, Chemistry, and Philosophy.
The Humanities and Social Sciences have not as yet
responded to the solicitations. Students themselves
have contributed very little, with only $1,000 coming
from students, and most of these contributors have
been graduate students.
The lack of undergraduate participation is partly
attributed to the fact that the undergraduate solicitation was delayed until this week.
The letters that were to be distributed to the offcampus students could not be given out. The Post
Office has recently refused to allow the stuffing of the
mail boxes in Gilman Hall. All mail must have a name
and box number on it, and the committee did not have
the manpower necessary to perform this task.
Sandy Cohn, who recently took charge of undergraduate solicitation, is expected to take action in the
near future to increase the student participation on
the drive.
"Syracuse" Contributes
Last weekend's performance of The Boys from Syracuse aided the drive. In addition to donating the proceeds of the show to "The Difference" fund, the show
also entertained .ft hundred inner-city high school
students Friday night.

By TIM OLIVER
Half the subscriptions to the
1966-67 Hopkins concert series
have been sold to students, faculty and alumni, and sales will
soon be opened to the public.
Concert lovers will be offered an
additional treat by the annual
Baltimore Chamber Music Society series.
The University series, of six
concerts supported by the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation, will run, except for one
concert, Sundays in Shriver Hall.
The Chamber Music Society
series, featuring, as in seasons
past, artists of international
fame in programs of both standard and contemporary works,
will be held Sundays at 3:30 in
the auditorium of the Baltimore
Museum of Art.
University Series
The Shriver series will open
on November 13 with the Julhard String Quartet, called by

the Times "the very model of
modern string quartet playing at
its best."
Jean-Pierre Rampal and Robert Veyron-Lacroix, the French
flute and harpsichord duo who
received ten curtain calls and a
standing ovation from a capacity audience last year, will return
on December 18.
Mieczyslaw Horszowski, acclaimed by Newsweek as "the
least known of the world's great
Pianists," and who has accompanied many great musicians, including his old friend Pablo
Casals, will appear in concert on
February 26.
Quartetto Italiano
The Quartetto Italiano, to
which the Times attributes "intensity and beauty of sounds so
great as to seem larger than life
and fill the auditorium easily,"
will come on March 12.
The fifth concert will feature
the great Russian cellist Mstislav
Rostropovich at the Lyric Theatre on Wednesday, April 19.
Subscribers will return to
Shriver for the, final concert,
featuring the Virtuosi di Roma
and directed by Renato Fasano,
on April 30. According to the
Chicago
Tribune, "The
men play for Fasano as if their
lives hung in the balance . . .
Virtuosi is no idle word picked
to look well on a poster."

The campus parking problem
remains a perplexing one which
has yet to be solved. There are
approximately eight thousand
campus authorized vehicles for
some one thousand parking
spaces.

This situation is alleviated
somewhat by the fact that 5800
of the parking permits are issued to night students, but the
permits issued to day students,
faculty, employees, and guests
tax the present parking facilities.

Campus Notes
Spring Glee
The annual Spring concert of
the Hopkins Glee Club and the
Hopkins Orchestra will feature
parts two and three of Handel's
"Messiah". The concert will also
feature the voices of the Mary
Washington College Choir and
the solo voices of Laurie Kopec,
soprano; Ralph Marquis, Tenor;
and Frank Whitmore, bass.

Committee several years ago to
study the situation.
Besides issuing permits, the
committee must maintain the
parking lots and enforce its regulations. The committee makes
regulations it feels are necessary
for the safety of the campus
community. The blocking of
roads creates a fire hazard, prevents the passage of emergency
vehicles and hinders delivery of
necessary supplies.
The committee does not have
the funds to investigate the
problem of increasing the parking facilities. The university
authorized the hiring of a professional planning service to investigate this problem. The report of this group is expected in
the near future.

Curriculum Committee
The current plight of undergraduate education at
Hopkins is a well-established fact. Poor graduate instruction, insufficient course offerings in most departments, the small size of the teaching faculty, and incompetent advising have been lamented before. In the
recently compiled Report of the Undergraduate Committee for Curriculum Studies, its authors have successfully laid bare the relationship between these problems
and the general Hopkins approach to education, also providing concrete suggestions for improving the situation.
Because the departments are extremely graduatebriented, and due to the demands of the "publish or
perish" doctrine, the attention of the faculty is diverted,
not unwillingly, from the undergraduate student body.
Furthermore, the Report states, "proposals that the administration act to alter this imbalance involves a transgression of the traditional departmental autonomy. Most
faculty members feel that such autonomy should remain
because it preserves the freedom of the scholar." Many
administrators, we might add, go along with this philosophy.
While this approach embodies the "uniqueness"
of Hopkins, some modification is presently called for.
The administration will he characteristicly slow to react, although the combination of the Schools of Philosophy and Engineering Science into one School of Arts
and Sciences suggests that interdepartmental communication could improve, facilitating changes in basic academic requirements and scheduling, and encouraging
the establishment of more interdepartmental courses.
More importantly, the administration could encourage
professors to teach more courses by awarding promotions to good teachers as well as by increasing their
aalaries.
For any real improvement to take place, however,
the faculty in the various departments will have to
modify their views in favor of increased teaching responsibilities. Only in this way can qualified and interested graduate students receive the opportunity to teach
specialized courses in their particular fields, as has been
suggested, thus helping to alleviate the shortage of
courses. More thorough supervision and coordination
of graduate instructors also requires the belief by professors that the effort is worth it. There is no reason why
the departments on their own cannot effect the necessary
changes, if they are but willing to employ the current
departmental system more flexibly.
Dealing with departments individually and directly
proved a successful approach to the Undergraduate
Committee on Curriculum Studies in writing its report.
Professors were both frank and at least open to ideas.
In continuing to follow this approach, the Committee
may find the departments more responsive to the suggestions proposed in its Report.
The Committee itself currently hold ad hoe status,
view of its accomplishments to date, there seems
in
and
to he no reason to change it. Its greatest asset is the fact
that it is composed of concerned and informed individuals. It would be a mistake to destroy its influence by
making it a political plum for either the Student Council
or the administration.

THEATRE

'Syracuse'Funny Despite Faults
The Boys from Syracuse was a
funny play. It was not great
theater, it was not meant to be
great theater, but it was funny.
It was an attempt on the part
of one group of people to cause
another group of people to forget themselves for a moment and
laugh out loud. It succeeded admirably. One can not ask more
of a musical comedy.
The play can be criticized at
many points. It was amateurish,
many of the lines were trite,
slapstick cliches. Some of the
songs were badly written, badly
sung. But the production made
no pretense of being professional, and the trite lines were those
of George Abbott, not Theatre
Hopkins. The tone of the production was light, and it may be
said that those involved in producing the play viewed the task
of production and presentation
with just the right degree of seriousness. Never does the play become 80 heavy handed, the actors
so engrossed in themselves that
the primary object of the play,
humor, is forgotten.
None of the music can be described as great, but "Falling in
Love With Love" and "This
Can't be Love", come quite close,
and over the years have achieved
"standard" stature. "The Shortest Day of the Year" is one
everybody would rather forget.

REPUBLICAN BIAS

The Nixon Legacy: Circa 1966
By GEOFFREY LEBAR
It is clear now that the 1966
elections will in some way be a
referendum on the Viet Nam
War. Withdrawal or escalation
will not be the main issue,
though. Since all the Republican
candidates will be patriotic
Americans, their strategy will
not be to undermine the war
effort. The issue will center
around what Ambass:sador Goldberg confusingly calls the "credi-

bility gap." In simple terms this
means one's confidence or lack
of confidence in the government's
determination to carry out a
policy which it talks about.
The limited war in South Viet
Nam has lost much of its limited
character. The supply of career
soldiers, high school drop-outs,
and voluntary enlistees has been
used up. The tentacles of the
draft have now extended to

many college seniors who were
on their rightful way to graduate school. We have many such
people at Hopkins. Thousands of
other students will be taking
army scholastic tests to maintain
their IIS status. As more men
are touched by the war, a higher
interest in our Viet Nam policy
will develop.
Republicans must be very
careful and avoid reckless statements on this most serious international problem. Republicans
should look back to the legacy
of the Eisenhower and Nixon
years for advise on the war issue.
In those 8 years, not only was
peace maintained, but where
limited troop action was needed
It was carried out with dispatch
and success (Lebanon). In situations where long term stalemate
wars or unbearable political
tensions would result, Eisenhower and Nixon restrained
themselves (Hungary). John
Foster Dulles preached "brinkmanship" everywhere, but used

nuclear weapons and bombs nowhere.
Geography and logistics are
working against the U.S. in Viet
Nam as well as internal political
trouble. But these difficulties
should have been assessed before
the first U.S. adviser was killed
there in December, 1961. Obviously many mistakes were
made, especially concerning the
Diem government. As the Republicans fielded a candidate in
1952 who was able to end conflict in Korea in an honorable
fashion, so they may again in
1968.
Ironically in the Presidential
campaign of 1960, Richard Nixon
chose to stand and fight on the
foreign policy issue. Unfortunately, Quemoy and Matsu. Cuba,
Hungary, and Lebanon did not
stimulate the people. The nonexistent missile gap held the
stage as the defense issue.
The Nixon legacy on foreign
affairs is strikingly related by
Theodore White in his book,

The Making of the President

1960. In the meeting by which a
Vice-Presidential candidate was
chosen, there was a disagreement
as to whether the candidate
should be knowledgeable in
domestic or foreign policy. Governor Stratton of Illinois said:
"You can say all you want to
about foreign affairs, but what's
really important is the price of
hogs in Chicago and St. Louis.'
Nixon declared, "If you ever let
them the Democrats) campaign
only on domestic issues, they'll
beat us—our only hope is to
keep it on foreign policy."
Theodore White relates a
memorable speech of Nixon's at
Peachtree Street and Hurt Park
in Atlanta, Georgia on August
26, 1960. Nixon said, ". . May
I turn now to what I believe is
the overriding issue confronting
u.s in this election campaign..
You know what it is. Look at
those boys sitting around that
pool. We want those boys to
grow up in a world of Peace
without Surrender. (Applause)
Because we can have the best
social security program and the
best health program and the
best job that anybody can possibly imagine and it Isn't going
to make any difference if we're
not around to enjoy it. . . I sapto you today that there is no
man in the world who has had
more experience and who has
shown more ability to deal with
the Communist leaders across
the conference table than the
man I trust will be the next
Vice-President, Henry Cabot
Lodge, our representative at the
U.N. .. ." (White, p. 323-4) Republican leaders should dust off
those 1960 Nixon speeches about
Peace without Surrender and
then ask for the people's vote in
1966 and 1968.

To the Editors:
The Kline article (April 1,
1965) shot through with half
truths, generalizations, and typical Radio Moscow phrasing, suggests little more that the frustrating mewlings of a small boy
whose father has forced him to
stop using crayons on the walls.
Either as a statement of SDS
policy or as a factual account of
the Waverly incident it fails
miserably.
Mr. Kline, the breadth of your
knowledge is truly astounding.
You seem to be an expert on the
inner workings of the modern
American corporation; you have,
no doubt, worked in top management positions for a number
of years. You profess to have
first hand information on our
foreign policy; undoubtedly Dean
Rusk calls you in regularly for
private briefings. And your firsthand account of what really goes
on in Vietnam is truly remarkable, particularly for one who
objects violently (oops, sorry,
non-violently) to being sent

there; how many months have
you spent in Vietnam as an onthe-spot observer? Lawyer, economist, foreign affairs expert,
political scientist, management
consultant, war correspondent:
how wonderful to have all this
in one so young!
Ah, but there is a fly in the
ointment; the true hoppie liberalarts-well-rounded-etc.
outlook
seems to be missing! Have you
visited the ghetto that is East
Berlin, Mr. Klein? Have you
talked with the refugees from
the Hungarian massacre of 1956?
Have you been corresponding
regularly with any of our men
in Vietnam? Or is this to be considered just a typical Wall Streetcapitalist-inperialist - aggressor propaganda, something that just
isn't done by Loyal SDS members? How is it that we never
see SDS protest any wars but
those in which SDS member!.
may have to fight?
Let's be serious, Mr. Klein. TI-w
guys over there are fighting
not to preserve our "economic
spheres of interest" (I presume
you mean by that that our corporations have huge holdings in
rice paddies?) — but to keep
the boat from rockIng while you
get on your soap box and
squawk about what they're doing. They're fighting to preserve
the rich American system which
now feeds, clothes, teaches,
houses, and pleasures you-the
same system you are castigating.
Bluntly, you're living as a leech
on their labors—which is pretty
disguisting in itself — but to
have you protest their labors
would be ridiculous were it not
so revolting.
Richard Oles
Editors note: Mr. Oles is
coach of the Fencing team.

A surprise winner last Saturday, the varsity baseball team
gets a chance to show home fans
this was no fluke when it hosts
Washington at noon tomorrow.
Slated to pitch for the Jays
Is the recently-resurgent Amy
Michelson, while Jim Elder, a
standout in last week's upset,
will be held in reserve. The only
other home game remaining is
a makeup contest with Franklin
and Marshall on May 12.

Division M.A.C. play, fell victim
to a then winless Hopkins club
by a 5-4 score.

Plebe Tangle On Tap
For Frosh Stickers
By JED LUCHOW
With four straight victories to
their credit, the freshman laorosaers meet the Plebes at the
Naval Academy this afternoon at
3:30 P.M.
Following a 9-1 win over St.
Paul's this past Tuesday, the
Baby Jays went out to scrimmage the varsity stickers for another sixty minutes of exercise.
In the St. Paul's game John
Gorczyk made four goals, Charlie
Goodell two, Cliff Barton one,
Will Scroggs one, Jim Feely one,
and Phil Buck three assists.
Adds to Middies
The starting line-up was the
same but coach Fewster made a
few changes on the second midfield. Barton, who had seen
limited action in the Bainbridge
and Severn games, scored first
In this game. Artie Guerin, the
other addition, showed tremendous speed and great improvement in his stick handling.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL 29, 1966

Ten Angles In
On Army Upset

A team composed of four Hopkins varsity distance runners
won the four mile relay in near
record time at last Saturday's
Mason-Dixon Relays, held at
Gallaudet College in Washington.

While these four stars were
competing in the relays, the rest
of the varsity trackmen were
losing a triangle meet to Dickinson and Ursinus. The weekend

LETTER

Goalie John Kelly looked great
despite a cold in the back. All
season long he has given the defense enough added confidence
for them to turn in equally fine
performances. Mike Clark showed
great hustle against the city's
top scorer by not only holding
him scoreleg but allowing him
only five shots.
New Goalie?
Kelly had seven saves in the
game but he was taken out in
the last three minutes to ease
his back. Mid-fielder Scroogs
then went into the net and came
up with a save himself.
Psych for Two
With only two games left, the
ability of the Baby Jays will
really be tested. They face a
well-conditioned but less skilled
Plebe team today and then face
even tougher competition from
the Maryland frosh in one week.
That game will be played in College Park at 3:30 P.M.
